title: LDAP Injection
overview: <paragraph>Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is used by web applications to access and maintain directory information services. One of the most common uses for LDAP is to provide a Single-Sign-On (SSO) service that will allow clients to authenticate with a web site without any interaction (assuming their credentials have been validated by the SSO provider).<paragraph></paragraph>LDAP injection occurs when untrusted data is used by the web application to query the LDAP directory without prior sanitisation.<paragraph></paragraph>This is a serious security risk, as it could allow cyber-criminals the ability to query, modify, or remove anything from the LDAP tree. It could also allow other advanced injection techniques that perform other more serious attacks.<paragraph></paragraph>The tool was able to detect a page that is vulnerable to LDAP injection based on known error messages.</paragraph>
remediation: <paragraph>It is recommended that untrusted data is never used to form a LDAP query.<paragraph></paragraph>To validate data, the application should ensure that the supplied value contains only the characters that are required to perform the required action. For example, where a username is required, then no non-alphanumeric characters should be accepted.<paragraph></paragraph>If this is not possible, special characters should be escaped so they are treated accordingly. The following characters should be escaped with a '\':<paragraph></paragraph>* '&' * '!' * '|' * '=' * '<' * '>' * ',' * '+' * '-' * '"' * ''' * ';'<paragraph></paragraph>Additional character filtering must be applied to:<paragraph></paragraph>* '(' * ')' * '\' * '/' * '*' * 'NULL'<paragraph></paragraph>These characters require ASCII escaping.</paragraph>
